abstract.p: Letter from Michael Harvey says Michael Ignatieff's May 15 Op-Ed on UN's failed peacekeeping efforts in Sierra Leone points up need for bold reinvention of UN's ability to resolve conflicts

block.p: Michael Ignatieff (Op-Ed, May 15) is right that United Nations peacekeeping efforts are broken, but it would be wrong simply to give up on peacekeeping. What is needed instead is a bold reinvention of the United Nations' ability to resolve conflicts.

Michael Ignatieff (Op-Ed, May 15) is right that United Nations peacekeeping efforts are broken, but it would be wrong simply to give up on peacekeeping. What is needed instead is a bold reinvention of the United Nations' ability to resolve conflicts.

The world needs a permanent standing United Nations army, with its own integrated command structure, logistical support, weapons and stable budget. Staff the 100,000-person army with permanent volunteers from member countries; make sure that a citizen of the United Nations member country that contributes the most in dues occupies the top spot; and give permanent Security Council members veto power over any deployment of the army.
Only when we get serious about organizing robust United Nations armed forces will the era of real peacekeeping begin. How many Rwandas and Sierra Leones do we really want in the next century?
